data.title: 'Maria Miller becomes culture secretary' diff viewer (1/2)
data.text: Version 1 Version 2 Maria Miller becomes culture secretary Maria Miller becomes culture secretary 2012-09-04 12:40:03 UTC 2012-09-04 13:15:03 UTC (35 minutes later) Maria Miller – a junior minister in the Department for Work and Pensions – is the surprise replacement for Jeremy Hunt as culture secretary in David Cameron's first major cabinet reshuffle.Maria Miller – a junior minister in the Department for Work and Pensions – is the surprise replacement for Jeremy Hunt as culture secretary in David Cameron's first major cabinet reshuffle. The 48-year-old MP for Basingstoke was minister for disabled people – and her appointment will be a significant promotion for somebody who had not been marked out as a potential successor to the much-criticised Hunt.The 48-year-old MP for Basingstoke was minister for disabled people – and her appointment will be a significant promotion for somebody who had not been marked out as a potential successor to the much-criticised Hunt. She will also become minister for women and equalities in addition to the DCMS responsibilities, a position previously held by Lib Dem Lynne Featherstone, adding to her responsibilities in what is already considered a wide-ranging and sometimes disconnected department.She will also become minister for women and equalities in addition to the DCMS responsibilities, a position previously held by Lib Dem Lynne Featherstone, adding to her responsibilities in what is already considered a wide-ranging and sometimes disconnected department. Miller said: "I am delighted to have been appointed as the culture secretary by the prime minister and am very much looking forward to tackling the many challenges that the role will bring."Miller said: "I am delighted to have been appointed as the culture secretary by the prime minister and am very much looking forward to tackling the many challenges that the role will bring." Her CV suggests she has some experience of the industry: before becoming an MP in 2005, she had two stints working in marketing and advertising at Grey, the ad agency.Her CV suggests she has some experience of the industry: before becoming an MP in 2005, she had two stints working in marketing and advertising at Grey, the ad agency. Between those roles, Miller worked at oil giant Texaco in marketing and business development and at PR company Rowland, which was then owned by Saatchi & Saatchi.Between those roles, Miller worked at oil giant Texaco in marketing and business development and at PR company Rowland, which was then owned by Saatchi & Saatchi. The new cabinet minister, who finished her education with an economics degree at the London School of Economics, was brought up in South Wales – is married to Iain with whom she has three children. The new cabinet minister, who finished her education with an economics degree at the London School of Economics, was brought up in south Wales and is married to Iain with whom she has three children. She inherits a department responsible for the disparate activities of sports, arts, and media – and will have to take on issues ranging from the Olympic legacy, final report of the Leveson inquiry and a restive arts sector contending with public-spending cuts. Don Foster, the Lib Dem spokesperson on culture, said he did not know Miller at all well, but had been told by other MPs that she was a good choice. "From what I've heard, she is somebody who will work well as a coalition partner, and has the ability to think outside the box."Don Foster, the Lib Dem spokesperson on culture, said he did not know Miller at all well, but had been told by other MPs that she was a good choice. "From what I've heard, she is somebody who will work well as a coalition partner, and has the ability to think outside the box." However, he voiced concern about the level of responsibility being added on to the ministerial brief. "She will have to find a way of dealing with the dual responsibility for culture and equalities at a department that may not be big by Whitehall standards, but touches on issues that people care passionately about from sport to libraries."However, he voiced concern about the level of responsibility being added on to the ministerial brief. "She will have to find a way of dealing with the dual responsibility for culture and equalities at a department that may not be big by Whitehall standards, but touches on issues that people care passionately about from sport to libraries." Prior to becoming an MP, Miller was touched by controversy when she appeared in a Tory political broadcast that was heavily-criticised for misleading viewers by casting party members as regular punters in an attack on Tony Blair. Prior to becoming an MP, Miller was touched by controversy when she appeared in a Tory political broadcast that was heavily criticised for misleading viewers by casting party members as regular punters in an attack on Tony Blair. The broadcast ran in 2000 and criticised the former prime minister for not telling the truth, using the slogan: "Tony Blair is all mouth and no delivery", while Miller worked as a board director at PR agency Rowland Company. The broadcast ran in 2000 and criticised the former prime minister for not telling the truth, using the slogan: "Tony Blair is all mouth and no delivery", while Miller worked as a board director at Rowland. Miller, a Conservative party member since her 18th birthday, played down accusations she had misled viewers and that the Tories had been "caught out" by having her appear in the ad and come across as a disgruntled Labour voter.Miller, a Conservative party member since her 18th birthday, played down accusations she had misled viewers and that the Tories had been "caught out" by having her appear in the ad and come across as a disgruntled Labour voter. She told PR Week that she appeared as a favour for an "old friend". "I just spoke to the camera about what matters to real people," she countered. "There was no rehearsal and no script". She told PR Week that she appeared as a favour for an "old friend". "I just spoke to the camera about what matters to real people," she countered. "There was no rehearsal and no script." Miller subsequently went on to be stand for the Conservatives in Wolverhampton North East in the 2001 general election.Miller subsequently went on to be stand for the Conservatives in Wolverhampton North East in the 2001 general election. The same Tory party political broadcast attracted the attention, and ire, of a number of national newspapers. A number of titles, including the Daily Mirror and The Guardian, ran scathing pieces highlighting that a Conservative parliamentary researcher Paul Morgan appeared as a a member of the public, when in fact he worked for the husband and wife team of Nicholas and Ann Winterton, Tory MPs for Macclesfield and Congleton.
